headline: Chicken Piccata with Artichoke Hearts
description: Feel like a cooking star when you whip up this deliciously simple Italian chicken piccata with artichokes and a savory lemon sauce using only one pan!

video.description: Savory chicken piccata with artichokes in a lemony white wine sauce.
video.name: Chicken Piccata with Artichoke Hearts

name: Chicken Piccata with Artichoke Hearts
recipeIngredient: 4 skinless, boneless chicken breast halves, pounded 1/2 inch thick and cut into thirds
1 (13.75 ounce) can artichoke hearts, drained and chopped, liquid reserved

recipeInstructions.text: Mix together the flour, garlic powder, salt, pepper, and Italian seasoning on a plate. One by one, dredge the chicken pieces lightly in the prepared flour mixture.
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Cook the chicken pieces for 2 minutes per side, or until nicely browned. Remove from the skillet and set aside.

Using the same skillet, cook and stir the garlic and onion until translucent, about 5 minutes. Pour the white wine into the skillet, turn the heat to high, and cook until the wine reduces by half, 4 to 5 minutes. Add the chicken broth, lemon juice, artichoke hearts, reserved artichoke liquid, and browned chicken to the skillet. Reduce the heat to medium and cook until the sauce thickens, about 20 minutes. Stir in the capers and butter.

review.reviewBody: Fantastic recipe that reminded me most of piccata that I'm familiar with. I did use a cornstarch slurry at the end (1 tb CS:2 tbs water) and it took 30 minutes instead of 20. For sure this will be in our regular rotation. Thank you for posting it!
Delicious!
Delicious! Great for the whole family.

Read the reviews. My husband didn't.. It's runny and there's no flavor. The liquid sauce drains all the flavor from the artichokes and capers. Pick another recipe. Sure ppl are giving it higher stars but they all amended the recipe. Even the original author amended it in a comment.

This was so tasty! Made it exactly like it said. Just cut it in half since there was just the 2 of us. I will definitely be making this again. Made with anger hair pasta, a grilled romaine salad, and garlic bread.
amazing !!!!
I sliced the chicken. In 1/2 inch pieces. Then fried. And added a little more wine. Was delicious
So so good!

I love all the ingredients of this recipe. I have also had chicken Piccata at a favorite restaurant so I was excited to try and had some idea what to expect. My husband and I are split on this; he thought it was great (5 stars) I thought it was good but not that memorable (3 stars) so I settled in the middle at 4 stars for this review. We followed the recipe exactly except I cooked in my cast iron pan. While he was licking his plate, I was more meh. Served with mashed potatoes (that’s how the restaurant I tried this serves it) and sautéd green beans. Glad I tried! And for the record, my hubby is a fan!

My family really enjoyed this served over angel hair pasta. This made a lot of sauce when prepared as is. I was concerned it would be too salty because of the caper brine, but it was fine. I used quartered artichoke hearts snd did not chop them further - halves may have made for a neater looking ostentation. All around excellent dish.
I left out the Italian seasoning and used lime juice instead of lemon juice. It was delicious - a definite keeper!
Great recipe, that I’ve made many times for my wife and kids. Quick and easy to make, but very classy and tasty to serve over rice. Wish I had this recipe back in my single days!

We've been making this recipe, ingredients as-is, since 2012 and it never disappoints. I'm finally reviewing since we're making it once again. We only tweak the cooking since we use an old-timey electric skillet from the '60s (an appliance heirloom!).

Nice weeknight meal. I followed the directions for the flour coating, but it turned out to be way to much. For 2 ppl, I used 1 large 19oz chicken breast cut for thicker filets. Followed the chicken searing time, but didnt get much of browning, so went a couple minutes longer. I only used 1/2 onion but increased to 3 garlic cloves. I used a Chenin Blanc white wine, squeezed fresh meyer lemon juice. Unfortunately, I forgot to reserve the artichoke liquid, but I dont think the flavor suffered. Overall I liked the recipe and will make this again when I'm in the mood for artichoke hearts.
Absolutely delicious. I made this in the crockpot, sautéed the chicken first then threw everything in at once it was wonderful served over spaghetti. We even shared with our neighbors.

I made this recipe as written, but I thought it was too salty and there was too much onion, otherwise it had good flavor. Next time I make it I will leave out the brine from capers, and the liquid from artichokes and I'll use maybe a quarter of an onion.
Served with sautéed garlic spinach and it was delicious!
I made this and also added grape tomatoes! Outstanding! Shared the recipe with a friend now she's an "Allrecipes" cook too! Thank you for posting this!
Excellent recipe! Feel free to add extra stock, wine, and lemon juice. Can’t go wrong with more sauce!
THE BEST! Thank you for sharing your recipe! I didn't change and thing (my chicken was thicker, so simmered for 40 minutes). Served with a bed of rice - can't wait to have the leftovers!
Recipe fine, i didn't have wine and just used 1/2 can broth , however i cut up half a lemon skin on into thin slices and added to broth for 3 minutes and then put chicken back in to thicken the sauce
This recipe is delicious. I had all the ingredients on hand and followed it exactly. I wouldn’t change a thing!

Since we are currently on quarantine here in NYC, I was bored and wanted to do something with chicken breast. I came across this recipe and since we love picatta and artichokes I figured this was a win and it sure was!! Family loved it and there was none left. Some things I did change however was, I doubled the amount of lemon juice, I used marinated artichoke they have more flavor and used the liqued from it. Also I saved the left over flour that was used to bread the chicken so that I can add some at the end to thicken up the sauce. I also added fresh parsley towards the end. The recipe is a keeper!
I made the recipe per directions. It was okay, but I thought it was bland
It was fairly simple and the taste fantastic. I did not use wine or chicken broth. Substituted vegetable broth for both. Worked out well!
This is the BEST chicken piccata that I have ever had! And I made it!

This is delicious! I ended up using that sauce on all sorts of veg because it was so good.

I did use chicken bone broth instead of stock, because I had some, and that added a certain depth to the sauce, IMO. 

Big thumbs up from my partner. He loved it, too.
Excellent
Excellent recipe. We like tomatoes so I always add what I have around whether it’s a can of fired roasted, jar of julienne dried in oil or fresh tomatoes with juices!

Thanks for the recipe but not a fan. Color drab green, broth weak and watery, artichokes bland and unchewable, chicken seasoning barely discernable, angelhair a poor pairing, at least the pasta could have been enjoyable. The least remarkable least enjoyable dish I've made in quite some time.
This recipe was absolutely delicious!!
I made this just like recipe said except I had marinated artichokes in my cupboard. It was delicious and we loved the extra sauce to pour over my vegetable side dish.

This was a family favorite for sure! Easy enough to make on a weeknight, delicious enough to make for company! I was looking for something different to make with some leftover artichoke hearts and I am extremely glad I came upon this recipe. It was very easy to make, I followed the instructions exactly and it was terrific. I really liked using the angel hair for this one which provided a delicate contrast to the lumps of chicken and artichokes.
Easy, fast and oh so tasty!
Delicious.
The sauce is delicious. And you can make it so quickly. Buy thin chicken or have your butcher flatten it to save time. I added fettuccini. Excellent

For the amount of work involved, I thought this recipe was only ok. As written, it tasted overwhelmingly of artichokes. I'm not sure I'll make it again, but I might try it with about half a can of artichokes and no artichoke juice, to give the other flavors a chance. I might try chicken breast tenders next time also, in the hope that the thinner cuts will absorb more flavor. The thick sauce was really nice, and I think this recipe has potential.
Love it easy to make
I doubled the recipe. It was fabulous the way it was written!

This came out pretty good. I used a full lemon and doubled the garlic powder and black pepper but otherwise followed the recipe. Also, I bought thinly sliced chicken so no meat beating required. I'm not completely sure about timings since my chicken browned much faster than 2 minutes per side and my onions started becoming brown instead of translucent so I dumped the wine in fairly soon after seeing that. The wine also evaporated much faster. I ended up eyeballing it. I'm pretty new to cooking so maybe I did something wrong, but it came out delicious despite that! Next time I might try without the butter. The flavor is good but I want to have it be a bit healthier.
Mom and I had this last night and it was a hit!! And when my 93 year old Mom loves something you know we will enjoy this again.

It was delicious. My only complaint is that I felt it was a little bit too salty, but that maybe because there was already salt in some of the additions. I recommend it- especially as it is easy and uses things I already have in my kitchen..

The sauce came out a little watery for my taste (did not add the juice of the artichoke) I thought of adding a little flour to thicken the sauce, so I used a bit of the seasoned flour from the chicken. Accompanied the dish with angel hair pasta like suggested and a potato rose.
I have made this a few times and while it is good, my family & I prefer the Quick Chicken Piccata recipe which is also on this site.

I made this exactly as written and it was really good. Next time I will brown the chicken a little longer, for looks, probably add less of the artichoke liquid and definitely more capers. Thanks for a great recipe!
Great recipe! I made it but added cherry tomato halves to the dish just after the Artichoke hearts for added taste and color.
Excellent sauce. Easy to increase the servings and my family loved it.

This was a great dish-loved by my husband who’s not a chicken lover! We like garlic so I added another clove then served it over angel hair pasta. Since it’s a pretty simple & not spicy dish I’ll be sure to make this in a larger quantity ahead of time for busy family visits!

I added extra white wine and broth, due to other reviews, and still needed to add more later. I cut the breasts horizontally instead of pounding them, She Who Must Be Obeyed said I should have pounded them. She's the cook in the family, I'm just getting started since retirement. Taste wise, it was fantastic. I'm a huge fan of chicken piccatta, and this did the trick. I put it over angel hair pasta, again, going with the reviews, and I get to enjoy it again because I made plenty for leftovers!
I am constantly trying to find a CP recipe that I love. Until this, I had not. Thank you for sharing this recipe. It was DELICIOUS!
I used this recipe as the base for the dish. I’ve learned what needs more or less and changed the technique a little bit to make it my own. I still use this when getting ready to make the dish.

I did all of this recipe as described, but I sous vided the chicken to 165 degrees for several hours to have precisely controlled temperature and maintain juices and tenderness. Otherwise my sauce was as described in the recipe. I served it over linguine seasoned with ghee and minced garlic. The final step only took a few minutes as all I had to do was brown the chicken and add the sauce. Awesome!

Very easy! Was delicious and pretty quick to make. I used juice of one lemon, a little extra chicken stock, and a little extra wine. I served it with TJ's Long grain brown rice, black barley, daikon radish seeds blend and sauteed spinach mix. It was a huge hit! Can't wait to make it again!
I omitted the capers, as my husband needs a low salt version. It was a bit time consuming, but it was worth the effort. It was fairly easy. I am kind of new at cooking, and it was actually very good!
Good recipe, didn't make any changes but next time I would add a little more seasoning to the flour mix, increase the lemon(or add zest) and reduce the artichoke liquid and the capers liquid.
Excellent recipe. Next time, though, I'll add a bit less liquid when simmering.

I have tried so many ways to make this dish but I think this one is the one I'll go to from now on. It really tasted great. I made no intentional changes (I didn't have capers but used peppercorns in brine which is similar and my artichokes were in oil with seasonings but I rinsed that off). But even with those differences the flavor was wonderful. Will definitely make this again!! Thanks

Made this fir dinner lastnight and it was so delicious. My husband said it was delightfully aromatic when he walked in the door from work. 
The only thing different I did was add corn starch to thicken the sauce just a bit and added more garlic since we love garlic in this house. 
I’m thrilled to of do be this recipe and cannot wait to make it again.

This dish would have been a five if it had called for baby artichokes. I used just one large Breast and cut it laterally for 2 servings, I don't know what their feeding chickens now but the chicken breasts are getting enormous! I cooked this for two and it was plenty. I did however make the sauce as printed and it was plenty for linguini too. I used the quarter cup of capers but not the brine they were soaked in, too salty and strong. I also did not add any artichoke liquid for the same reason. After I added my wine and reduced it, I added 2 TBS of fresh cream, brought it back up to a simmer and added my chicken and chokes and served it over linguini. 
We go to Italy every year in April while the artichokes are in full season, but not the tourists. Every restaurant in Rome has a dozen ways to fix them plus a house special. With this dish they would use the baby chokes, sliced in half, choke removed and then saute it with the sauce till tender, a lot of Romans will just get a huge plate of the baby chokes and forget the rest.

This recipe is a much better spin on any Chicken Piccata recipe I have found (which I love!). Make sure to watch the video for good hints and different spins on the original recipe given. I use to hate cooking but recipes like this has changed that!
This was fantastic! I used chicken tenders and Chef John’s technique of sifting flour onto the chicken (less waste). Definitely a good choice for company
Easy & delicious. My family loved it. I will certainly make it again. I served it with egg noodles and green beans.

This is a taste as you go, add a bit of this and that, .. kind of recipe. Good base recipe and with my tweeks it came out amazing. For the sauce I did NOT add the juice of the capers(unless you want it to taste like very strong dill pickles), or the artichoke juice. I did add fresh thyme, oregano,basil, salt and pepper. It just needed more flavor and these did the trick. Added a few sun-dried tomatoes and just added more or less of the wine/lemon/chicken broth until I got the flavor I wanted.

This was a fantastic meal. My husband and I prepared it together and it was very easy to make. Even better was sitting down to eat it and we really enjoyed it. The capers and artichokes - along with their juices - really give this dish a lot of flavor. It was truly a delight. We will be making this again. Thanks for the recipe!
I loved it and it was a breeze to make! I made no changes to the recipe - great job!

I enjoyed this dish...but I like artichokes and thought it had great flavor. My wife and kids who are not as big of fans of artichokes, just thought it was ok. I'll make it again for myself, but likely not for the family.
Yummy!
This was great. Followed it as written. The leftovers are amazing too!
Served this over spaghetti squash, and it was a stay-in date night hit! Leftovers were delicious as well.
Made exactly as recipe said and it was wonderful. Served it over wide egg noodles. This recipe is a keeper.
It was very tasty
followed directions, very good

This is a good recipe. I read the reviews and took a couple of hints, though. The chicken needed more fat to cook, so I added some butter to the mix. I shredded the onion and added more garlic (always enjoy a little more). I used marinated artichoke hearts and drained both them and the capers instead of saving the juice. 

I think the recipe is good as is, but I wanted a little less sauce. I added spinach leaves at the end to add color. My husband cleaned his plate. Thank you for the recipe!

This was a very good recipe! I did add some fresh sautéed mushrooms and some sun dried tomatoes... both were a great addition. I also would add a bit more garlic to the one pod in the recipe. Other than that... it's perfectly delicious!
I enjoyed this recipe but made a couple of changes. I added mushrooms and a rou when the broth would not thicken. Taste was good,especially the chicken but would add more lemon next time

OMGosh!!! This is phenomenal!!! I can't have gluten, dairy, or soy so I substituted gluten free flour and pasta. Kudos to you because this is so very delicious. I feel confident enough in making it to serve it to guests!!

This recipe was delicious !! After reading some of the reviews, the only change I made was to add a little corn starch to the sauce to thicken it up. Other than that, it didn't need to be changed. Excellent !!

Make it all the time since first trying it. It is the BOMB! Its easy and fancy, the capers, white wine (I use Barefoot Moscato in the little bottles), and artichokes with the liquid just lends such a good flavor, everyone loves it. I put it over rice or angel hair pasta. Last time I made it, used a no salt broth and felt something was lacking, yeah-salt, so I added more and also added twice as much capers which made it perfect!!!!!
This recipe was wonderful. I doubled it and served it over linguine. Can't wait to have the leftovers tonight!
soooooo good just as written

This was a big hit last night. I did not have all the Italian spices for the flour coating. I did not use the wine or the butter. I like my onions to be more roasted than translucent so I pan roasted half a large Vidalia. I also added pan seared baby Bella mushrooms. I used chicken thighs and kept them warm in the oven until serving time so the coating stayed nice and crispy. The richer flavor of the thighs was nicely paired with the lemon sauce.
This is delicious, but I didn't add as many capers, and cut the amount of flour in half. Overall very easy and tasty.
Made this for my husband's birthday dinner, it was so yummy, the wasn't any left over!
This was excellent. The chicken is tender with the artichoke hearts and capers adding a complex flavor.
Excellent! Better than any restaurant!
This is one of my family's favorite recipes. The artichoke really adds the perfect touch! This is one of those rare recipes where I don't change anything- a true 5 star recipe in my esteem.
Fairly easy and good but I would decrease the amount of lemon juice next time. I found the sauce to be too tart. One tablespoon of lemon juice would probably have been sufficient, possibly even less.

Okay, I made some changes! I kept the basic spirit of the recipe and followed almost all of the suggestions from the reviews. I didn't have any artichoke hearts, used mushrooms. I cooked some bacon - crisped up my chicken in the bacon fat with a bit of olive oil. Set aside . Saute shallots, garlic, mushrooms melted butter with leftover flour and zest and juice of a lemon, with the capers after the wine reduction. DELICIOUS! Added my pasta with swiss chard. real good meal.

I used chicken tenderloins instead & added sautéed mushrooms ... served it with farfalle pasta 
It was a hit !
Thank you, thank you for this awesome recipe! The only modification, I added brussel sprouts! Delicious! Thank you!
I would use half the amount of chicken broth, it never thickened and the sauce was too liquid. The flavors were great though.

So absolutely easy and delicious. I did add mushrooms but basically stuck with this recipe otherwise. Served over whole wheat spaghetti and loved every bite. Not too bad for you but tastes naughty and fancy. Even my 7 and 9 yr old loved it. Will definitely make again.
Update 11/3/2016 made again, loved it just as much. Definitely a winner.
I left out the black pepper and the Italian seasoning.
love it. I also like to add olives to the recipe.
It was excellent!!
My son has celiac, so I just substituted GF flour for the regular flour. The only ingredient I omitted were the capers (didn't have any). And the only other suggestion is to use less liquid.
Oh so good. Substituted red wine for white as I drank all the white, whoops! Still delicious.

I made this recipe today. I must say, I followed the recipe hower, not to the "T" as I never measure anything, but I did basically follow all the ingredients and steps and I made the recipe with 2 chicken breast for the 2 of us. We both loved the meal. I served it over spaghetti (all the noodles I had) and I served a salad along side....oooh, I actually thought the recipe needed a bit of green so I added some Collard Greens that I had in the fridge to the pasta water and then quickly into the picata sauce.......will definitely do a repeat on this one! Thank you....
At had to add flour to the skillet it did not thicken up like I hoped it would, I just put in 2 tbsp.
